name: lentil production | lentil | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24767/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 tonne of dried lentil product with a dry matter of 84% at minimum during May-August, 2019, at 12441.26 ha lentil farms located in the Province of Alberta, Canada. Farms have yield of 1619.12 kg dried matter per ha for this crop cycle. The system boundaries include the production of all of crop inputs (e.g. seeds, fertilizers, crop protection products, and fuel). There is an estimated 0.65 kg of N fixation per tonne of lentils produced in this region that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. Irrigation is not included since it is rarely performed for lentils in this region. Sowing date for the crop is May, 2019 and harvesting date is August, 2020. Seeding rate is 0.07 kg/tonne of lentil production. Fertilizer applied contain nitrogen (as N) 5.40 kg/tonne, phosphate (as P2O5) 20.63 kg/tonne, potash (as K2O) 1.22 kg/tonne, and sulfur (as S) 2.45 kg/tonne. Predominant crop protection applied contain active ingredients of Glyphosate 608.23 g/tonne, Sethoxydim 35.13 g/tonne, and Pyraclostrobin 14.71 g/tonne. Machinery is used for tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, and burndown/desiccant application with total fuel consumption of 12.06 kg/tonne.

Starting inputs for this activity include seed, fertilizer, crop protection products and fuel on the farm. This activity begins with soil preparation about 37 weeks after the harvest of the previous crop. The soil is prepared for cultivation in 1st week of May and sowing of seeds started about 5 days after soil preparation.

This activity ends with lentil drying to <16% moisture at farm gate. Carbon and nitrogen emissions associated with above- and below-ground biomass are accounted for using the DNDC model. This model was also used to calculate a nitrogen fixation credit that can be included as an avoided use of N fertilizer for the next crop in the rotation. However, this was not included in this model due to data presentation restrictions. For lentils in this region, the N credit was estimated to be 0.65 kg/t.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Soil cultivating date for the main crop: April - May 2019; Harvesting date main crop: August, 2017-2019. The soil cultivation, sowing and harvesting dates are the data collected by the farmers. Total time from date of sowing to date of harvesting comes to 119 days. The data is collected for three crop cycles. The cycle of one year is considered for entry in ecoinvent.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Refers to weighted-average production in the Province of Alberta, Canada
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Production of lentil includes farm practices from tillage (disk), land rolling, seeding, tillage (cultivator), swathing, harrowing, fertilizer application, in-crop herbicide application, foliar fungicide application, foliar insecticide application, combining, post-harvest herbicide application, burndown/desiccant application, to drying.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Geographical location of each farm was used to identify the Reconciliation Units (soil and climate based provincial divisions) identified by Agriculture and Agri-Food Canada (AAFC) and AAFC Reporting Zone (ecozone) to which each farm belongs. Production-weighted average datasets were calculated for each ecozone.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Site-specific field data were collected via survey from prairie province lentil producers for crop rotation, seeding rate, machinery and fuel use for field operations (e.g., tillage, harrowing, harvest), farm inputs (e.g., fertilizers, pesticides), and electricity for crop drying. Production weighted averages were calculated for the region. Outliers were removed from reported fuel use data based on visual inspection.

flow.name: lentil
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

exchanges.description: Modelled, farm-level emissions from plant protection product application were modelled based on the active ingredients for each substance. As per Margni et al. (2002), it was assumed that, regardless of the timing of the products, 76.5% of the active ingredient of each agricultural plant protection product is emitted to soil, 8.5% to water, and 10% to air. This means a total of 95% of the applied active ingredient is emitted back to the environment. The last 5% is taken up by the plant and was therefore not considered as an emission in this model. (Reference: Margni M, Rossier D, Crettaz P, Jolliet O (2002) Life cycle impact assessment of pesticides on human health and ecosystems. Agric Ecosyst Environ 93:379â€“392. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0167-8809(01)00336-X)

exchanges.description: Modelled, farm-level emissions from plant protection product application were modelled based on the active ingredients for each substance. As per Margni et al. (2002), it was assumed that, regardless of the timing of the products, 76.5% of the active ingredient of each agricultural plant protection product is emitted to soil, 8.5% to water, and 10% to air. This means a total of 95% of the applied active ingredient is emitted back to the environment. The last 5% is taken up by the plant and was therefore not considered as an emission in this model. (Reference: Margni M, Rossier D, Crettaz P, Jolliet O (2002) Life cycle impact assessment of pesticides on human health and ecosystems. Agric Ecosyst Environ 93:379â€“392. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0167-8809(01)00336-X)

Modelled with using the DeNitrification DeComposition (DNDC) -Management Factor Tool (DNDC-MFT) that was developed by Smith et al, (2010). The Canadian version of DNDC that has been used in this study was developed to include a crop growth model for cultivars grown in Canada as well as the impact of snow dynamics, crop biomass, and residue management on soil temperature (Dutta et al, 2016). (References: Dutta B, Smith WN, Grant BB, et al (2016) Model development in DNDC for the prediction of evapotranspiration and water use in temperate field cropping systems. Environ Model Softw 80:. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2016.02.014
The heavy metal emissions are calculated by SALCA-heavy metal (Freiermuth 2006) using the ecoinvent LCI calculation tool for crop production.

Peat moss is used as a proxy to model the used inoculum. The amount is calculated by dividing the peat moss mass by its density (207 kg/m3).

(2002), it was assumed that, regardless of the timing of the products, 76.5% of the active ingredient of each agricultural plant protection product is emitted to soil, 8.5% to water, and 10% to air. This means a total of 95% of the applied active ingredient is emitted back to the environment. The last 5% is taken up by the plant and was therefore not considered as an emission in this model. (Reference: Margni M, Rossier D, Crettaz P, Jolliet O (2002) Life cycle impact assessment of pesticides on human health and ecosystems. Agric Ecosyst Environ 93:379â€“392. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0167-8809(01)00336-X)

Modelled, farm-level emissions from plant protection product application were modelled based on the active ingredients for each substance. As per Margni et al. (2002), it was assumed that, regardless of the timing of the products, 76.5% of the active ingredient of each agricultural plant protection product is emitted to soil, 8.5% to water, and 10% to air. This means a total of 95% of the applied active ingredient is emitted back to the environment. The last 5% is taken up by the plant and was therefore not considered as an emission in this model. (Reference: Margni M, Rossier D, Crettaz P, Jolliet O (2002) Life cycle impact assessment of pesticides on human health and ecosystems. Agric Ecosyst Environ 93:379â€“392. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0167-8809(01)00336-X)

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: The heavy metal emissions are calculated by SALCA-heavy metal (Freiermuth 2006) using the ecoinvent LCI calculation tool for crop production.

Modelled, farm-level emissions from plant protection product application were modelled based on the active ingredients for each substance. As per Margni et al. (2002), it was assumed that, regardless of the timing of the products, 76.5% of the active ingredient of each agricultural plant protection product is emitted to soil, 8.5% to water, and 10% to air. This means a total of 95% of the applied active ingredient is emitted back to the environment. The last 5% is taken up by the plant and was therefore not considered as an emission in this model. (Reference: Margni M, Rossier D, Crettaz P, Jolliet O (2002) Life cycle impact assessment of pesticides on human health and ecosystems. Agric Ecosyst Environ 93:379â€“392. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0167-8809(01)00336-X)

Modelled with using the DeNitrification DeComposition (DNDC) -Management Factor Tool (DNDC-MFT) that was developed by Smith et al, (2010). The Canadian version of DNDC that has been used in this study was developed to include a crop growth model for cultivars grown in Canada as well as the impact of snow dynamics, crop biomass, and residue management on soil temperature (Dutta et al, 2016). (References: Dutta B, Smith WN, Grant BB, et al (2016) Model development in DNDC for the prediction of evapotranspiration and water use in temperate field cropping systems. Environ Model Softw 80:. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsoft.2016.02.014

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Land use change (LUC) combines land transformation areas calculated with the adapted 'Direct Land Use Change Assessment Tool' version 2014 developed by Blonk Consultants and the carbon losses from soil organic carbon (SOC) and vegetation (VEG) as calculated in ecoinvent v3. See 'WFLDB-Guidelines.pdf', available at <https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports>.
